questions.text: The additional mechanism by which class 1A drugs additionally prolong action potential duration is:
questions.solution:
Class IA antiarrhythmics block K+ channels leading to prolongation of action potential duration.

The main action of class IA antiarrhythmics is blocking Na + channels causing: 

  • Slowing the upstroke of the action potential
  • Slowing conduction
  • Prolonging the QRS duration

questions.text:
Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channel blockade?
  1. Procainamide
  2. Phenytoin
  3. Flecainide
  4. Mexiletine

questions.solution:
Phenytoin and mexiletine which are class IB antiarrhythmic drugs have the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channel blockade.

They show the fastest dissociation kinetics to Na+ channel blockade (<1 sec).

questions.text: An athlete diagnosed with atrial fibrillation was administered an antiarrhythmic drug.  Several hours later, he complains of lower abdominal pain and not having passed urine since admission. Examination reveals a palpable bladder. Which was the most probable drug administered?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of urinary retention. Disopyramide, a class 1A antiarrhythmic is the drug most likely to cause these symptoms in this patient.

It causes prominent anticholinergic side effects like urinary retention, dry mouth, blurred vision, precipitation of glaucoma, and constipation. 

It is the drug of choice for vagally mediated atrial fibrillation such as sleep-induced or atrial fibrillation in athletes.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
QT prolongation is seen with quinidine. 

It causes torsades de pointes, a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A patient presents with sinus bradycardia and bronchospasm. She was previously diagnosed with AV nodal reentrant tachycardia and had been started on an antiarrhythmic drug. Which of the following drugs is most likely being used?
questions.solution:
Propafenone is the most likely drug being used in this patient as sinus bradycardia and bronchospasm are adverse effects seen with the use of this drug.

These side effects are due to its weak beta-blocking activity.

questions.text: Blurred vision in a patient being treated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Blurred vision is the most common dose-related non-cardiac adverse effect of flecainide therapy. 

Flecainide is a class 1C antiarrhythmic agent. It acts mainly by sodium channel blockade. It does not cause any change in the action potential duration. 

Flecainide is used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVTs): 

  • Atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT)
  • AV re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT)
  • Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter (without structural heart disease)

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has both class II and class III action?
questions.solution:
Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent with additional beta-adrenergic blocking effects. (class II antiarrhythmic action)

Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent that has an additional Na+ channel blocking effect. (class I antiarrhythmic action)

Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker with minimal/no action on cardiac Na+ and K+ channels.

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias. 

Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.

Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding lignocaine?

choices.text: In heart failure patients, both loading and maintenance doses are decreased
Indicated for prophylaxis of arryhythmias in all cases of suspected MI

questions.solution:
Lignocaine decreases the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with suspected MI. However, it increases mortality probably by precipitating heart block or congestive heart failure. Hence it is not routinely used for prophylaxis in MI patients but it is used only when indicated.

Gastrointestinal absorption of lignocaine is good but bioavailability is very less due to high first-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, it is not used through the oral route. 

Lignocaine has a high volume of distribution. The loading dose is required to achieve rapid action. 

In heart failure, both volumes of distribution and clearance are reduced. Both the loading dose and maintenance dose have to be reduced.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding antiarrhythmics?

choices.text: Sotalol has additional class II action
Esmolol has additional class IV action
Propranolol has additional class I action

questions.solution:
Sotalol has both class II (beta-blocker) and class III action (K+ channel blockade). Though it is a nonselective beta-blocker, as an antiarrhythmic, it is classified under class III. 

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional membrane-stabilizing action especially at higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action.

Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.

One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers of skin.

The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and photosensitivity.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Red man syndrome - Vancomycin
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: Chronic usage of an antiarrhythmic drug leads to optic neuritis and smurf skin or ceruloderma in a patient. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis and smurf skin (blueman syndrome or ceruloderma) are caused by amiodarone. It acts by blocking K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channels. It also blocks adrenergic effects. It does not block Cl- channels.

Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through the following mechanisms:

  • Blockade of transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents
  • Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery
  • Decreases Ca2+ current
  • Non-competitive adrenergic blockade

It is the drug of choice for acute treatment of VT and VF.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely in a patient who is on chronic amiodarone therapy?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity is not an adverse effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Pulmonary fibrosis associated with dry cough is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. It can rapidly progress and become fatal.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.

The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dronedarone is incorrect?

choices.text: It does not contain iodine moiety
Has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone
Less effective antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone
Dose adjustment has to be done in renal failure

questions.solution:
Dronedarone undergoes hepatic metabolism and hence dose adjustment is not required in renal failure as it is not excreted through the kidneys.

Dronedarone is a non-iodinated congener of amiodarone. Like amiodarone, it is a blocker of multiple ion channels. It has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone. It is less effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and is considered less antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone. 

Unlike amiodarone, it does not cause thyroid dysfunction or pulmonary fibrosis. However, it causes hepatotoxicity and increases the risk of stroke and heart failure.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG findings are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Verapamil and diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT.

Their mechanism of action is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure.

Dihydropyridines like nifedipine and amlodipine do not have any antiarrhythmic property.

Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1A / 1C antiarrhythmics

questions.text: Vernakalant is indicated in which of the following types of arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Vernakalant is a newer antiarrhythmic agent indicated in atrial fibrillation.

Its mechanisms of action include:

  • Frequency and voltage-dependent block of the early and late components of the sodium current
  • The muscarinic potassium current IKACh, which is constitutively activated in atrial fibrillation is also blocked

It is indicated for rapid termination of atrial fibrillation in patients with no or minimal structural heart disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause this condition.

Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmics.

Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval. They are also prone to cause torsades de pointes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the immediate management of a patient with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. 

Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.text: A patient who was recently diagnosed with a seizure disorder presents to the casualty with altered mental status. His ECG shows a prolonged QTc. There is history of sudden cardiac deaths in his family at an early age.  On further evaluation, a diagnosis of congenital long QT syndrome is made. Which is the most suitable pharmacological agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers like metoprolol are the mainstay of pharmacological therapy in both asymptomatic and symptomatic patients with congenital LQTS. They reduce both syncope and sudden cardiac death (SCD).

Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a disorder of ventricular myocardial repolarization characterized by a prolonged QT interval on the electrocardiogram that can lead to symptomatic ventricular arrhythmias and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

questions.text: An elderly patient with heart failure and atrial fibrillation is stabilized with digoxin. By what mechanism does it control the arrhythmia in this patient?

choices.text: Decreasing atrial repolarization by blocking Na+ channels

questions.solution:
Digoxin results in an increased vagal tone which helps in controlling the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation.

Increased vagal tone increases the AV nodal refractoriness due to blockade of Ca2+ channels. It also results in hyperpolarisation and shortening of atrial action potentials due to activation of ACh-mediated K+ channels in the atria.

questions.text: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.
